text: this could be how it all started before
you can make a stone tool you have to be
able to use a stone scientists from the
University of Georgia analyzed the
motions of these capuchin monkeys in
Brazil because they wanted to learn
about the dexterity they had with tools
so they tracked how high the monkeys
lifted the stones and how fast they
brought them down the captions didn't
just bang away they adjusted the force
of their blows depending on how well
they were doing cracking the nut oh
these aren't the only monkeys that use
tools a world away in Thailand another
group of researchers studied Burmese
macaques hammering open shellfish they
found 17 patterns of motion different
strokes for different stones and
different foods these monkeys are not
human ancestors but their activities may
well give us a glimpse of how the
ability to make stone tools evolved
you
